    ggtukey

    Ethan Bass

    ggtukey.Rmd
    library(ggtukey)
library(ggplot2)
library(palmerpenguins)
data(penguins)

    Simple boxplot with Tukey Letters:

    boxplot_letters(data=penguins, x=species, y=body_mass_g, vjust=-0.5, hjust=-0.3, type="global")
#> Warning in is.na(~): is.na() applied to non-(list or vector) of type 'symbol'
#> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`).

    Faceting

    Perhaps we want to break our penguin data by sex:

    boxplot_letters(data=penguins, x=species, y=body_mass_g, group=sex, vjust=-0.5)

    Or look for sex differences within our three species:

    boxplot_letters(data=penguins, x=sex, y=body_mass_g, group=species, vjust=-0.5)

    When there is a grouping variable, there are (at least) two possible ways to run the statistics that may yield different results. By default a global test is conducted where TukeyHSD is run on a full anova (aov) with class and year as interaction, returning all pairwise comparisons of these two factors. If the comparisons are independent, type="local" can be selected to run independent Tukey tests within each group.

    boxplot_letters(data=penguins, x=species, y=body_mass_g, group=sex, type="local", vjust=-0.5)

    Raw data can also be plotted in various ways using the raw argument to specify the desired geom for plotting raw data: e.g.Â geom_point (points), geom_dotplot (dots), geom_jitter (jitter).

    boxplot_letters(data=penguins, x = species, y = body_mass_g, group = sex, vjust = -0.5, raw = "jitter", alpha=0.6)
